climbs.name: Witch Wonder
climbs.fa: Eric Hendrickson, John Pinnette (70s) FFA - Mike Opuda (70s)

content.description:
An awesome classic two pitch crack climb that you'll want to do over and over. 

  For the first pitch you can either climb the bolted chunky monkey arête of Highlander (5.7) or slither up the dirty dihedral and slamming through a slot chimney (5.9) 

  For the second pitch follow the crack up and through a squeeze chimney that's quite a squeeze, on the scale of something like being born. Getting into the chimney's the crux. Then follow the easy crack the rest of the way up to the anchor bolts @ the top. (5.7) 

  It's a fun climb, with beautiful views. Bring some friends for a party because the belay ledge between the two pitches is huge!
content.protection: Nuts and a few medium to small cams is all you need.
content.location:
From the Roofs, walk right around the base of the cliff. The first awesome looking crack you see that has a giant flake chimney near the top of the cliff is Witch Wonder. You can follow the crack all the way down to the base. There's a line of bolts that leads up the blocky arête just left of the crack, that's Highlander. It's super visually striking and hard to miss. 

  You can abseil down off of Highlander's rap bolts, or do the short easy walk off.

content.description: Another classic!  Layback an obvious left-facing flake to a face passing several bolts to ledge.  Belay here or continue forty feet to a bolt anchor.  The original second pitch (Breakfast of Champions, 5.9+) is now easily combined with the lower section by continuing straight up the face past bolts to a new anchor below the room on the Cross-over ledge.  The original route had only one bolt on the face above the initial flake.
content.location: Right of Reckless Abandon.

content.description: Diagonals right past 3 bolts (2 hangers have been removed) to trees.
content.location: Far left on the practice wall between Dirty Meat and Seamless.

content.description: Months of top-roping led to the F.A of this crystal pinching marathon. Run it out from ground level, or start at the far right end of wheaties ledge. Climb the steep bleached face past five bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.protection: 5 Bolts to a cold shut anchor
content.location: This is the furthest right route on the wheaties ledge.

climbs.name: Walk on the Mild Side
climbs.fa: Ward Smith, Chris Smith, Peter Lataille.

content.description: Classic. Follow the right traversing line of bolts from the far right end of wheaties ledge. Follow the bolted traverse out right to a pleasent ledge, move right until anchors. Continue up a steep face past an assortment of bolts, to a dike. Continue up the dike to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Begins at the far right end of wheaties ledge, and traverses right for a large portion of the steep face.

content.description: Pumpy climbing on polished granite. Steep for a 5.8 trad climb.
content.location:
In the middle of practice wall, on the left side of a gargantuan ledge. 

  See photo

content.description: Follow a finger crack to a tree ledge then move past several bolts to anchor.  Originally done with one bolt and tricky stopper placements.

climbs.name: The Tax Is Too Steep
climbs.fa: JB, DN, John Crocker, Mike Avery

content.description:
This route starts on a 15 sq. ft. platform (roughly) to the right of "Texas Two Step".  Right off the deck you'll find a nice grippy (and sharp) start into a nice friction section, which will lead you to the crux. You'll find more sharp quartzite crystals and crimpers at the crux (located over half to 3/4 way to the top). This portion of "The Tax Is Too Steep" will leave you balancing on the tip of your toes and praying for a 'thank God hold' to magically appear before you cut loose. The route ends/tops out on the edge of "Catwalk" ledge. "Catwalk" ledge runs the distance from directly above "Texas Two Step", continuing several yards past "The Tax Is Too Steep". 

  All in all its a very good climb to warm up to and work on your balance. From what I gather you can start this route below the 15 sq. ft. platform where "Texas Two Step" instead of taking the ledge staircase that leads to "The Tax Is Too Steep".
content.protection: Consists of 4 bolts. Bring decently long slings to extend your top rope anchor over the round, but jagged, ledge aka "Catwalk".
content.location: Taking the Southern Trail (off of Rt. 180) you will pass through a good bouldering field straight on up the The Main Faces (which is streaked in black and white, and well over 100' high). Once you reach the main cliff face you'll follow the cliff out left a little ways till you encounter a short broken up face known as "Practice Wall". Continue along "Practice Wall" till you see a cleaned off ledgy staircase which will lead you up to the 15' platform at the base of "The Tax Is Too Steep".    Between "Texas Two Step"(5.10c) and "Corner Line"(5.4) which are all located on Practice Wall (right). There are several social trails leading up to the main crag area, so please stay on the more heavily established trails.

content.description: A short, powerful route on a boulder on the southern approach trail.  Moves from left to right, and then right up the face of this boulder.  Some of the moves may be a little bit easier if you are tall.
content.protection: Three bolts to an anchor.  Easily top roped if you don't like the looks of smacking in to the ledge if you fall off some of the early moves.
content.location: Walking down the trail from the right end of the practice wall into the boulder field, keep an eye out on your left for this boulder.

content.description: PG retrobolted face climb
Short slabby section to a ledge into a dihedral, step right and continue straight up to a new looking two bolt anchor with chains and rap rings.
content.protection: Small to medium cams. I placed two purples and 1 yellow C4 camalots.
content.location: Look for the obvious wide dihedral (wider than Help [5.7])

content.description: Face climbing to a shallow corner.
content.location: Practice Wall Left

content.description: A fine moderate trad route.  Pull through horizontal cracks on  clean vertical rock for 30ft.  Pull the crux at the end of the vertical section (5.8), and follow easy low angle rock up to anchors.
content.protection: Trad; small and medium nuts and cams
content.location: From the bottom of the main face, walk along the base of the cliff to the right to the north/east end of the cliff line.  Pass several moderate routs and notice a series of clean square cut holds straight up the cliff that make Slice of the Gunks.

content.description: Originally a boulder problem
Crack and thin seem.
A fun, short boulder problem of a route. It could be bouldered with a lot of pads. Start directly beneath the bolts and climb straight up on decent crimps.

A short, bouldery route that requires some strong fingers. Start up easy terrain with a crack for hands and slabby feet until you reach the first bolt. Head straight up using a short crack on the right, then some crimps, followed by a slopey seam. The crux comes at the top. Once you've figured out how to get there, topping out is easy. 

 A quick way to set up a toprope is to run a lap on the bolted first pitch of Crossover.
content.location: Right end of the Practice Wall, just before the ledge ends.

content.description: Start on the slab for sales pitch clip a low bolt, straight up to the left facing flame to the right of sales pitch. Two new bolts up high protect the crux slightly reachy move and top out. You can redirect for a top rope using a large sling around the tree right on the top out and use sales pitch anchors. Or use the tree as an anchor, but it’s on the smaller side.
content.location: Just right of sales pitch

content.description:
A good way to access the Toilet Bowl feature - not to be missed. 

  Start right of Cereal Killer on a clean slab below a small roof.  Climb the slab on ledges trending right to below the roof.  Go around the right side of the roof and up the face following a groove.  Follow the bolt line (10b) or stay slightly right (easier) up to a ledge with a bolt anchor.
content.protection: Bolted but further protection can be found at the base of the roof using small pro.
content.location: Below a small roof between Lemmings in Lycra and Cereal Killer.

content.description: Climb up the right facing corner, which forms the right end of the 5.10 Ledge.  A nice route when dry, however this route often wet.    This is the best way to access the 5.10 Ledge even when its damp.
content.location: Right end of 5.10 Ledge.  From Witch Wonder (on main face) walk right along bottom of cliff to find the right facing corner.

content.description: Overheard as I rack up for this climb: "That thing is so thin!" Is it a steep slab or a less than vertical face climb? You be the judge. Crimp and technique your way past 4 bolts to the anchor. Somewhere in there are a few good holds and some fun moves. The toughest moves come between the first two bolts and just before the last bolt. Pitching off just before the anchor is heartbreaking.
content.protection: Four Bolts to anchors. Stick clip recommended.
content.location: This is the steep blank face just to the right of Eagles Direct and left of Wheaties.

climbs.name: Rainy Day Deliverance
climbs.fa: Jon Tierney, Eric Inman, Mark Leblond

content.description: Straight up the headwall.
content.location: Broken Wall

content.description: Unique for clifton, this route offers positive holds and pumpy climbing through the largest roof at the cliff. P1 passes through a couple "bivy ledges" aiming for a right facing flake with a bolt. After the flake, look left for a bolted belay on a large blocky ledge. P2 Take on the daunting diamond shaped roof, by traversing right past fixed gear and some bolts.
content.protection: Mostly fixed gear. bring small gear.
content.location: Starts directly behind the Oak tree by the roofs section--impossible to miss--this climb takes on the largest roof in the section.

content.description: Start at crack just right of ledges.  Awkward moves up the crack to ledge with giant block.  Continue up on large holds past horizontals and a bolt.
hand/fist crack
content.location: Left of Entrance Wall and Left Practice Wall

content.description: Most 3rd class
content.location: Broken Cliff

content.description: Recomended. Thin Cristal pinching leads to a classic mantle over a bulge. THe bulge distinguished this climb from surrounding climbs.
content.protection: 7 bolts, leads to a two bolt anchor on a ledge.
content.location: The second furthest right route on the main face, 10 feet left of a large dropoff.

content.description: The steep face just to the right of Wheaties (the distinct layback crack). The climb just keeps on going. Climb past of total of 7 bolts.
content.location: THis climb is located just to the right of wheaties.

content.description: Boulder to a finger crack.
content.location: Practice Wall Left

content.description: up 5.7 slab past 2 bolts to horizontals on blocky holds past small overhang crux to 2 bolt belay   up flakes to classic face climbing on blunt arete crux to another 2 bolt belay
content.location: to the left of large roofs (90'from ground) the 5.7 slab is unmistakable

content.description: Short slab to blocky climbing followed by crack running through a dihedral at the upper portion of the climb. A little stemming in the dihedral or laybacking keeps the upper portion interesting. One of the better pitches on the practice wall, IMO. Good lead for the 5.7 leader as it takes great gear
content.protection: Cams up to #2 C4. Chains and rap rings at the anchor.
content.location: Look for the short slab at the base and dihedral at the top (right of upside down staircase 5.8).

content.description: Looks can be deceiving. The top half of this climb is a juggy crack, while the bottom is a harmless looking corner/face. Getting off the ground and making any upward movement is tricky but may involve some slopers, crimps, and/or heel hooks. The crack is so thin at the bottom it is barely usable. Once you get to the left hand sidepull, you can make a huge move up into the good holds, plug some gear and finish it up.
content.protection: Hard to protect the bottom. May be best to lead with crash pads as you boulder the crux and then plug gear post-crux.
content.location: Just on the left side of the Easy Stuff corner, above CWT Direct and right of CWT, on the left end of the cliff.

content.description: An obvious, inviting slab with four bolts.  Originally a top rope route or solo, this is now a safe and appealing lead at a moderate grade.  Rappel from tree.  A broken hold raised the grade a notch.
blocky climbing with finicky gear. Bit dirty when we climbed it. Not the best lead for a 5.7 climber due to finicky gear down low.
content.protection: Cams up to a #1 BD C4. a nut or two will work. Chain anchors at the top.
content.location: Just left of the the 5.8 and 5.10 (trad) face climbs. Right of the roof on the 5.10 roof climb

content.description: Right Facing corner/bulge system on the entrance wall.  Some tricky moves, a big reach or two, and thin footwork throughout.  Much of the difficulty is finding the holds and realizing the moves.  The rest of the difficulty is dealing with small/sharp crimps and awkward stances.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.  Bring a couple shoulder-length runners to extend your power point over the lip at the top.
content.location: The "Entrance Wall" is located to the left (while looking at the wall) of the practice wall and below it.  The climb itself is directly below "Easy Stuff," a distinct dihedral topped by a large block.

content.description: First 5.12 at Clifton.
content.location: Practice Wall Left

content.description: A difficult line requiring many top ropes. Climb a slab at ground level, until you junction with walk on the mild side at a ledge. Continue up a shallow curving arete on the left. Their is an uncompleted second pitch.
content.location: Begin at ground level. THis is the second line of bolts on the left side.

content.description: Traverse to the right from Easy Stuff past bolts.
content.location: Practice Wall Left

content.description: This is the distinct dihedral corner topped by a large block to the far left (while looking at the wall) of the "Practice Wall."  Follow the finger crack up the back of the dihedral until you reach the block at the top.  Then work the horizontal crack to the left until you are out from under the roof.
content.protection: Finger sized stoppers will get you up the vertical crack, and 2 or 3 cams will get you through the horizontal crack (bd sizes 1 and 2).  There is an anchor on the side of the block once you get out from under the roof and you can belay from the cliff top.
content.location: "Easy Stuff" is located at the far left end of the practice wall.  Look for the large dihedral topped by a large block.

content.description: An awesome route with thin slab/face climbing plus a small roof.   Start up a slab trending slightly left past bolts and some small ledges to base of roof.  Pull over the roof to an alcove and move right to an airy bolt anchor around corner.  165' of rope will just get you back to the ground.
content.protection: A bolted route.  If you are timid bring a .75 camalot to protect a runout below the roof.
content.location: After Crankenstein below the huge roof.

content.description: The most direct line on the cliff. This route climbs the distinct white  bleached streak 25 feet to the right of wheaties, 5 ft to the righ tof a large dropoff. Climb the steep face to the first band of horizontals. More crystal pinching through the middle tierpast ledge to faint arete and anchors.
content.location: The distinct white bleached streak 5 ft to the left of the large dropoff.

content.description: A variation to the first pitch of Where Eagles Dare or a great single pitch on its own. Follow bolts directly up the thin face to the finger crack. Plug some small gear and climb the crack to the anchor.
content.protection: Two bolts on the face. Bring small stoppers for the crack. Fixed anchors at the top.
content.location: The face below the finger crack, just to the right of Where Eagles Dare.

content.description: Essentially a bolted boulder problem. Climb the weird, short corner and exit onto the crystal slab. Balance and crimp strength are your friends. Top it out.
content.location: 25 meters into the woods, below the Broken Cliff.

content.description: Tackle the shallow, right facing dihedral and straight up the face above. The moves are not exactly obvious which makes it a little bit of fun although it could use a cleaning.
content.location: The leftmost route on the crag, starting 50' left of Chinese Water Torture Direct.

content.description: A classic line, although rarely repeated due to major runouts with groundfall potential and 1/4" bolts placed on hooks on the initial on-sight ascent. This route climbs the dark face 20' to the right of wheaties. The first bolt is located 30+ feet up. Climb to a comfortable ledge, then continue into a left facing dihedral.
content.protection: Not much. Three bolts, and small to medium gear for the dihedral. Bolts will likely be replaced in the future.
content.location: The dark, somewhat dirty face 20' to the right of wheaties.

content.description: The old guidebook says that this route likes to spit you off. It's techy, delicate, powerful, and actually quite fun. It starts with a low angle scramble up to the ledge, then figure out a sequence through the tiny holds and tiny feet up the vertical wall and over the first bulge. The first jug on the route comes at 2/3rd height and is followed by a little boulder problem to get over the next bulge. Big moves between big holds will get you to the anchor. Don't blow the last move or you'll have to go through it all again for the send!
content.protection: Eyebolts to bolt anchor. [ Admin.  Note- See Comment about anchor.]
content.location: Beneath the roofs and at the base of Bivy Route is a wide trail and clearing. 20' right of this, the cliff butts to a tree. This starts about 6' left of the tree. Also the 2nd bolt line after Bivy Route. Look up at Eagles Gift, the pointy roof on the right, and the anchor for this route is down on the ledge to the left.

climbs.name: Crankcase
climbs.fa: Peter Lataille, Jennifer Smith, Ward Smith, Steve Damboise, 4/86

content.description: An easy finger crack leads into crimpy and reachy face moves. Two bolts protect the face climbing which tops out at a ledge with a beefy two bolt anchor.
content.location: Appealing and striking finger crack on the right end of the practice wall.

content.description: Easy moves up big blocks then a moderate left facing corner. Tops off onto a ledge to the right.
content.protection: Nuts, Cams. Two bolt anchors at the top
content.location: Located in the broken section between the two practice walls. Obvious corner above the biggest of the clearings at the base of the cliff.

content.description: Scary face climb
content.location: Practice Wall Left

content.description: Move right from start of Stevie's Spanking up thin moves to below a roof.  Traverse right on horizontals.  Variation: continue right up corner.  Both routes were originally protected with a pin.
Face climb
content.location: Practice Wall Left

content.description: Climb up vertical rock on mostly positive holds.  This route is unique due to the absence of the usual Clifton crystal pinching.  The dike futures offer an array of jugs, side pulls, and a few pockets.  The crux comes about mid way up the climb where you need to place a cam in a horizontal and make a move up to a nice side pull/jug.
content.protection: The route is sport with one very notable exception.  You will need a cam (BD size 0.75) to protect crux.  There is an obvious horizontal crack to plug the cam into.  Be sure to place the cam in the left side of the crack where crack is parallel, and not in the slightly flaring middle portion of the crack.  There are bolt anchors at the top.
content.location: Looking at the main face, walk along bottom of cliff to the right of Witch Wonder about 60 ft.  The bolt line begins above a small low angle slab.

content.description:
Starts 20' right of Punks in the Gunks, below the largest point of the above roof.  Start up a bulge (1st crux) perhaps getting a spot until you clip the first bolt.  Then up low angle climbing with positive holds.  Come up to a small roof (second crux) - pull it on the right on positive holds.  Continue up to a prominent ledge (last tricky part) that's big enough for a bivy! 

  This route is great and well-protected, do it!
content.location: Under the the most protruding part of the big roof, 20' right of Punks in the Gunks.

content.description: Climb a ten foot, right-facing flake then make a long reach to a finger jam over the room.  Just when you think it's over, balance straight up face to join Alleyway.  Another popular testpiece.
Finger/Hand crack
content.location: Left of Entrance Wall and Left Practice Wall

climbs.name: Another Bolted Face Climb
climbs.fa: Paula King, Mark Tebaldi, JB, WS, CS 1990

content.description: Sustained delicate moves over small crimpy holds.  Although not a pure slab climb, the angle is less than vertical.  The climb is a little bit dirty at the end.
content.location: From Witch Wonder, walk to the right along cliff line.  Located on left end of the broad ledge (known as the 5.10 Ledge) about 25 ft above trail.  Access the 5.10 Ledge by the Route of Choice 5.7

content.description: One of the first sport routes to take on the steep main face from the bottom up. Follow a slab up past two bolts to the start of walk on th emile side on wheaties ledge. Continue up the s-shaped stripe to a belay at horizontals. COntinue up past the crux bulge and several more bolts to an anchor.
content.protection: Bolts. Bring medium to large gear for the belay at the top of P1.
content.location: This route starts at ground level, down and right from wheaties ledge. Its the furthest route to the left that starts at ground level.

content.description: The path of least resistance moving left on angular hold and a ramp then straight up and right to a ledge.

This route starts on Alleyway and continues up instead. Aim for the single bolt. It's a bit more of a natural and aesthetic line, because it runs straight up. The climbing is mostly <5.7 with a 5.8 crux move.
content.protection: Small to medium cams and one bolt. There are a few horizontal gear placements.Chains with rap rings at the anchor.
content.location: This route starts on Alleyway (5.5) instead of heading left, continue straight up through a slight overhang towards a single bolt.

content.description: You know you wanna touch those huge jugs. Work your way up to the roof, then pull through on huge holds with a hard move coming onto the face above. From here, continue up the black face on small holds past several bolts.
content.protection: Several Bolts and a hidden pin out right just above the roof.
content.location: This route starts at the very base of the cliff, 20 feet left of the overhangs right end.

content.description:
There's a bolted climb right next to Bivy Route that has some fun moves? Really? This one was slightly furry but is now cleaning up again. A tough start leads to a section of large holds above. The last section, just past the last bolt, holds a slopey crux. Once you pull through, you can stand up on the ledge and ponder what you intend to do...

 You can clip the anchors for Crankenstein and lower down (this is not the original route, let's call it Shortline), or you can plug some cams and follow the crack out the roof out left. Once you reach the notch, head on up to the anchor and hope the rope is long enough to get you back to the ground.
content.protection: All bolts to the ledge, then cams out the roof. Bolted anchor. You may need a 70m rope.
content.location: Find the roofs area and look up. On the right side of the big roofs you'll see the anchor. The start of the climb is the small corner beneath a bolt.

content.description: Broken holds have made this climb even harder.
content.location: Practice Wall Left

climbs.name: Where Eagles Dare
climbs.fa: Aided by Pat Jodice, Freed by Jim Ewing

content.description: The best 5.10 in Clifton.    P1: Start up the left side of a blank face to horizontal with hidden piton, traverse right and up the finger crack to a ledge. Continue past a bolt to crossover ledge. P2: Follow out right and up to a gear belay at horizontals. P3: Traverse left onto the face and climb up the exposed face past three bolts to a bolt anchor, or top out.
content.protection: Bring a Wide seletion of gear. Bolts are found just when you need them. Fixed anchors are found at the top.
content.location: This route is located down and right from the practice wall. It is the furthest route left on the steep face. The finger crack on pitch one is unmistakable.

content.description:
Looking up from the Wheaties ledge.

 Eagle Bluff is Clifton's most popular and well-known climbing area with over 130 sport and trad routes as well as a collection of boulders that hold over five dozen problems. Climbers of all kinds will find enjoyable lines. Trad cracks? Check. Hyper-technical slabs? Check. Overhanging sport climbs? Check. Multipitch? Check. Routes range from 5.easy to 5.12d with a few projects still waiting for an ascent. The boulder problems are mostly in the V0-V3 range, but there are a few unfinished lines and a handful of V5-V6s.

 Access is secured and most of the anchors are brand new thanks to the efforts of the CCA.

 There are now 3 signed parking lots!

North Lot - Park here to have quick access to the Practice Wall and the left end of Eagle Bluff. This is also the best way to access the summit. 10 minutes to the climbing.

Overflow Lot - Located in the middle. The crowds are non-existent, so you may never have to park here. ​​​​ South Lot - Park here to walk into the boulders or to access the middle or right end of Eagle Bluff. Allow 8 minutes to the boulders or 12-15 to the cliffs.

Finishing up Eagle Direct
